ALLEGATION:
The agency has not completed the children’s adoption timely. An expedited consent
for adoption was requested in April 2021. The request was returned for rework on
6/1/2021 and the rework has not been completed. Due to the adoption taking nearly
two years to occur, one of the children has aged out of foster care prior to being
adopted.
INVESTIGATION:
On 10/5/2021 I reviewed the allegations in the complaint.
On 10/6/2021 I spoke with Complainant X related to the allegations by telephone.
Complainant X confirmed the allegations in the complaint. Complainant X reported
the DD children have been under Spectrum’s care since 11/21/2019. The children
became permanent wards of the state, with a plan of adoption shortly after Spectrum
took responsibility for the case. The children have never had a placement change.
They remained in the care of an aunt, who wishes to adopt them. Almost two years
later, Spectrum has yet to complete the children’s adoption. The Complainant X
reported due to Spectrum’s delayed work on this case one of the children has aged
out of the system without the permanency of adoption. The other children’s
adoptions are held up due to a lack of follow up actions from the agency. The
agency requested an expedited consent request for the children’s adoption in April
of this year. The consent request was sent back to Spectrum for needed rework on
6/1/2021. As 9/21/2021 the agency had yet to complete that rework to move the
adoption forward. They finally submitted the rework on 10/1/2021.
Complainant X reported this complaint is the first concern being expressed related
to the agency. The case was previously under Oakland County Department of
Health and Human Services (DHHS) and Complainant X is not aware of any
concerns from that entity. Complainant X reported after expressed concerns and
frustration by the court with the lack of adoption progress, Lapeer County DHHS
conducted a case review and discovered these complaint issues and concern
related to reports and system upload issues. A meeting was held with Spectrum’s
administrative staff on 9/23/2021. The agency did not have an excuse or explanation
for the delays and lack of work. They just reported they would look into the matter.
On 10/22/2021, I interviewed Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) 2 related to the
allegations by telephone. FCS 2 reported employment with agency in February of
2021. She was assigned supervisory responsibilities for the DD Children’s adoptive
5

case in April 2021. She also served as the adoption case worker for the case from
April 2021. A contractual worker had been assigned to the case prior to FCS 2. FCS
2 reported they were trying to get the children’s adoptions completed before Child A
turned 18. FCS 2 believed all adoption paperwork was in place prior to her
assignment to the case. As to the problem with the MCI consent request being
returned for rework, FCS 2 reported believing there was an issue with the DHS-3130
needing to be corrected and some children protective services issues or
documentation getting taken care of which took a long time. She said the contract
worker was charged with completing the adoption evaluation; and was to stay in
contact with she and Administrator 1 on getting the children’s adoption completed.
The contractual worker left the agency, and the agency had to assess what was still
needed related to the adoption. FCS 2 was not sure whether she was still
responsible for the case, but reported they have since requested consent and are
awaiting its approval.
On 10/25/2021, I interviewed FCS 3 by telephone related to the allegations. She is
the current foster care supervisor. Prior to her current role, she was the foster care
worker, not the adoption worker. She did not provide information related to the
adoption delay concerns.
On 11/22/2021, I spoke with Chief Administrator 1 about my preliminary special
investigation findings. I also advised her the original and recent MCI consent request
documentations were not uploaded into MISACWIS. Additionally, the family’s initial
adoption evaluation report is dated for 9/30/2021 and how was that when the agency
requested expedited consent in April 2021. Chief Administrator 1 advised the
9/30/2021 family adoption evaluation date is correct. She reported the worker did not
complete the family’s adoption evaluation report back in April. The worker apparently
sent paperwork to MCI without a family adoption evaluation report, which was a part
of the problem. Whatever consent paperwork the worker put together or may have
submitted to MCI is not available. Thus, MCI consent was not actually requested
back in April 2021.
Reviewed:
The MISACWIS record for Adoptive Parent E that showed:
 An Initial Adoption Evaluation (DHS-3130) for Adoptive Parent E shows with a
recommendation date of 3/30/2021 and a supervisory approval date as pending.
The report generates as a DRAFT document and is not complete.
 An Initial Family Adoption Evaluation report for Adoptive Parent E dated
9/30/2021; and DHS-612 Adoptive Family Assessment Addendum - Criminal
History report dated 10/1/2021.
The DD Children’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
 Spectrum accepted the children’s cases on 11/21/2019. Child A (age 18) was
made a Michigan Children’s Institute (MCI) ward on 11/21/2019. Child B (age
15) and Child C (age 11) were made MCI wards on 12/18/2019.
6

 The three children were placed in Adoptive Parent E’s home on 9/19/2019
and remain in that placement.
 No documentation related to when MCI consent was first requested or what
problems occurred.
 Documentation indicating the agency continues to pursue Child A’s adoption.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
(3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
directly responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the children,
their families, and other relevant individuals and be
primarily responsible for the development, implementation,
and review of service plans for the children and their
families.
ANALYSIS: The agency took acceptance of the children’s adoption case in
November and December of 2019. The agency staff did not put
forth efforts to timely process the children’s adoptions. The staff
lost sight of the status of the adoptions, whether adoption
consent was requested as alleged and whether the contractual
worker had completed the family’s adoption evaluation back in
March or April of 2021. The family’s adoption evaluation was not
completed until 9/30/2021.
In this instance, the agency did not provide direct and effective
efforts related to working with relevant individuals towards
completion of the children’s service plan/permanency goal.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Family Team Meetings (FTMs) have not been completed as required. There are
several missing in the system.
Semi-annul transition meetings have not been completed as required.
INVESTIGATION:
On 10/6/2021 I spoke with Complainant X related to the allegations by telephone.
Complainant X confirmed the information in the complaint related to there being
multiple missing reports or required documents or signatures for service plans, and
missing family team meetings. Complainant X reported there have been three foster
care supervisors and two workers assigned to the DD Children’s case, but there is
not a primary adoption worker.
7

On 10/22/2021, I interviewed FCS 2 related to the allegations by telephone. FCS 2
reported not being sure why there would not be family team meeting completed. She
reported only being involved in one for September 2021.
On 10/25/2021, I interviewed FCS 3 by telephone related to the allegations. FCS 3
reported being the foster care worker (FCW) on the case prior to her current
supervisory role. She served as the FCW from March 2020 until June 2021 when
FCW 4 became the FCW. The case has since transferred to FCW 5 as of
September 2021. FCS 3 reported as the FCW on the case she completed the work.
She admitted it was true that many reports may not have been uploaded to
MISACWIS; and she has corrected much of that as of 9/27/2021. She reported she
and FCW 5 would be working to ensure all services are linked. She was not sure
why the work may not have been done prior to her assignment to the case. She has
only been the supervisor since June 2021.
FCS 3 reported FTM, Semi-annual transition plan meetings and service plans were
completed timely but not uploaded. She reported COVID issues impacted on her
uploading of documents.
Reviewed
The DD Children’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
 Information as listed earlier.
 FTMs documented for service plans reviews for July 2020- Sept 2021.
 Semi-annual transition plan meeting documents for 7/20/2020, 12/22/2020
and 10/8/2021. The latter one was late as one was due by 6/22/2021.
 Updated service plans signed by the worker and supervisor were not
uploaded in the system for service plans 1/7/2021- 4/6/2021 and 4//7/2021-
6/25/2021.
 Late youth and foster parent/caregiver signature on service plans for
1/7/2021-4/6/2021 and 4/7/2021-6/25/2021- Both were signed for 9/27/2021.
 Late adoption quarterly adoption progress reports for:
 4/17/2020-7/16/2020 approved 10/20/2020.
 7/17/2020-10/15/2020 approved 2/17/2021.
 10/16/2020-1/12/2021 completed 2/20/2021.
 4/16/2021-7/15/2021 approved 5/27/2021.
 7/16/2021-10/14/2021 completed 11/1/2021 approved 11/2/2021.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting,
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following:
Case plan development/Reassessment Updated service
plan (USP)
Within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
8

ANALYSIS: Per a MISACWIS review looking back to April of 2020, family
team meetings for updated service plans were documented.
Family team meeting reports (DHS-1105) associated with those
FTMs were uploaded.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting,
Semi-annual Transition Meeting
Beginning at age 14, Semi-annual transition meeting must occur
once every 180 calendar days to discuss a youth’s permanency
goal and identify supportive adults.
ANALYSIS: Per a MISACWIS review looking back to April of 2020 the record
showed Semi-annual transition plan meetings for Child A and
Child B for 7/20/2020, 12/22/2020.
The next Semi-annual transition plan meeting due in June 2021
was not documented. One was completed late on 10/8/2021.
The agency did not adhere to the standard.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
9

ANALYSIS: Timely completed, signed service plans and parent agency
treatment plan agreements (PATPA) were documented and
uploaded to the system except as follows:
 A worker and supervisor signed updated service plan for
1/7/2021- 4/6/2021 and 4//7/2021-6/25/2021.
 A supervisor signed PATPA for 4/7/2021-6/25/2021.
Additionally, signed quarterly progress reports were not
uploaded for:
 4/17/2020-7/16/2020.
 7/17/2020-10/15/2020.
 10/16/2020-1/16/2021.
 1/16/202104/15/2021.
Various adoption documents were not uploaded.
The agency did not adhere to the standard.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-8C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement.
Signature: When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee.
ANALYSIS: During the investigation, it was discovered the agency did not
adhere to the standard.
The 1/7/2021-4/6/2021 and 4/7/2021-6/25/2021 PATPA were
not signed timely by the youths and foster parent/caregiver.
Both were signed by the youths and foster parent/caregiver on
9/27/2021, which was more than 30 days of the report approval
dates.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10

APPLICABLE RULE
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
Quarterly adoption progress reports (DHHS-614) are to be
completed quarterly.
ANALYSIS: During the investigation it was discovered the following adoption
quarterly progress reports were completed late as indicated
above in this report:
 4/17/2020-7/16/2020.
 7/17/2020-10/15/2020.
 10/16/2020-1/12/2021.
 4/16/2021-7/15/2021.
 7/16/2021-10/14/2021.
The agency did not adhere to the standard.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current licensing status is recommend
November 22, 2021.
